Chapter 4.4:49: Each man was registered as the Lord had commanded Moses; and at the command of the Lord given through Moses, each man was assigned responsibility for his task of serving or carrying.

Chapter 5.5:2: Command the people of Israel to expel from the camp everyone with a dreaded skin disease or a bodily discharge and everyone who is unclean by contact with a corpse.

Chapter 5.5:3: Send all these ritually unclean people out, so that they will not defile the camp, where I live among my people.

Chapter 5.5:4: The Israelites obeyed and expelled them all from the camp.

Chapter 5.5:6: the following instructions for the people of Israel. When any of you are unfaithful to the Lord and commit a wrong against someone,

Chapter 5.5:7: you must confess your sin and make full repayment, plus an additional 20 percent, to the person you have wronged.

Chapter 5.5:8: But if that person has died and has no near relative to whom payment can be made, it shall be given to the Lord for the priest. This payment is in addition to the ram used to perform the ritual of purification for the guilty person.

Chapter 5.5:9: Also every special contribution which the Israelites offer to the Lord belongs to the priest to whom they present it.

Chapter 5.5:10: Each priest shall keep the offerings presented to him.

Chapter 5.5:12: to give the Israelites the following instructions. It may happen that a man becomes suspicious that his wife is unfaithful to him and has defiled herself by having intercourse with another man. But the husband may not be certain, for his wife may have kept it secret—there was no witness, and she was not caught in the act. Or it may happen that a husband becomes suspicious of his wife, even though she has not been unfaithful.

Chapter 5.5:14: to give the Israelites the following instructions. It may happen that a man becomes suspicious that his wife is unfaithful to him and has defiled herself by having intercourse with another man. But the husband may not be certain, for his wife may have kept it secret—there was no witness, and she was not caught in the act. Or it may happen that a husband becomes suspicious of his wife, even though she has not been unfaithful.

Chapter 5.5:15: In either case the man shall take his wife to the priest. He shall also take the required offering of two pounds of barley flour, but he shall not pour any olive oil on it or put any incense on it, because it is an offering from a suspicious husband, made to bring the truth to light.

Chapter 5.5:16: The priest shall bring the woman forward and have her stand in front of the altar.

Chapter 5.5:17: He shall pour some holy water into a clay bowl and take some of the earth that is on the floor of the Tent of the Lord's presence and put it in the water to make it bitter.

Chapter 5.5:18: Then he shall loosen the woman's hair and put the offering of flour in her hands. In his hands the priest shall hold the bowl containing the bitter water that brings a curse.

Chapter 5.5:19: Then the priest shall make the woman agree to this oath spoken by the priest: If you have not committed adultery, you will not be harmed by the curse that this water brings.

Chapter 5.5:20: But if you have committed adultery,

Chapter 5.5:21: may the Lord make your name a curse among your people. May he cause your genital organs to shrink and your stomach to swell up.

Chapter 5.5:22: May this water enter your stomach and cause it to swell up and your genital organs to shrink. The woman shall respond, I agree; may the Lord do so.

Chapter 5.5:23: Then the priest shall write this curse down and wash the writing off into the bowl of bitter water.

Chapter 5.5:24: Before he makes the woman drink the water, which may then cause her bitter pain,

Chapter 5.5:25: the priest shall take the offering of flour out of the woman's hands, hold it out in dedication to the Lord, and present it on the altar.

Chapter 5.5:26: Then he shall take a handful of it as a token offering and burn it on the altar. Finally, he shall make the woman drink the water.

Chapter 5.5:27: If she has committed adultery, the water will cause bitter pain; her stomach will swell up and her genital organs will shrink. Her name will become a curse among her people.

Chapter 5.5:28: But if she is innocent, she will not be harmed and will be able to bear children.

Chapter 5.5:29: This is the law in cases where a man is jealous and becomes suspicious that his wife has committed adultery. The woman shall be made to stand in front of the altar, and the priest shall perform this ritual.

Chapter 5.5:30: This is the law in cases where a man is jealous and becomes suspicious that his wife has committed adultery. The woman shall be made to stand in front of the altar, and the priest shall perform this ritual.

Chapter 5.5:31: The husband shall be free of guilt, but the woman, if guilty, must suffer the consequences.

Chapter 6.6:2: to give the following instructions to the people of Israel. Any of you, male or female, who make a special vow to become a nazirite and dedicate yourself to the Lord

Chapter 6.6:3: shall abstain from wine and beer. You shall not drink any kind of drink made from grapes or eat any grapes or raisins.

Chapter 6.6:4: As long as you are a nazirite, you shall not eat anything that comes from a grapevine, not even the seeds or skins of grapes.

Chapter 6.6:5: As long as you are under the nazirite vow, you must not cut your hair or shave. You are bound by the vow for the full time that you are dedicated to the Lord, and you shall let your hair grow.

Chapter 6.6:6: Your hair is the sign of your dedication to God, and so you must not defile yourself by going near a corpse, not even that of your father, mother, brother, or sister.

Chapter 6.6:7: Your hair is the sign of your dedication to God, and so you must not defile yourself by going near a corpse, not even that of your father, mother, brother, or sister.

Chapter 6.6:8: As long as you are a nazirite, you are consecrated to the Lord.

Chapter 6.6:9: If your consecrated hair is defiled because you are right beside someone who suddenly dies, you must wait seven days and then shave your head; and so you become ritually clean.

Chapter 6.6:10: On the eighth day you shall bring two doves or two pigeons to the priest at the entrance of the Tent of the Lord's presence.

Chapter 6.6:11: The priest shall offer one as a sin offering and the other as a burnt offering, to perform the ritual of purification for you because of your contact with a corpse. On the same day you shall reconsecrate your hair

Chapter 6.6:12: and rededicate to the Lord your time as a nazirite. The previous period of time doesn't count, because your consecrated hair was defiled. As a repayment offering you shall bring a one-year-old lamb.

Chapter 6.6:13: When you complete your nazirite vow, you shall perform this ritual. You shall go to the entrance of the Tent

Chapter 6.6:14: and present to the Lord three animals without any defects: a one-year-old male lamb for a burnt offering, a one-year-old ewe lamb for a sin offering, and a ram for a fellowship offering.

Chapter 6.6:15: You shall also offer a basket of bread made without yeast: thick loaves made of flour mixed with olive oil and thin cakes brushed with olive oil, and in addition the required offerings of grain and wine.

Chapter 6.6:16: The priest shall present all these to the Lord and offer the sin offering and the burnt offering.

Chapter 6.6:17: He shall sacrifice the ram to the Lord as a fellowship offering, and offer it with the basket of bread; he shall also present the offerings of grain and wine.

Chapter 6.6:18: At the entrance of the Tent you nazirites shall shave off your hair and put it on the fire on which the fellowship offering is being burned.

Chapter 6.6:19: Then, when the shoulder of the ram is boiled, the priest shall take it and put it, together with one thick loaf of bread and one thin cake from the basket, into the hands of the nazirite.

Chapter 6.6:20: Next, the priest shall present them as a special gift to the Lord; they are a sacred offering for the priest, in addition to the breast and the leg of the ram which by law belong to the priest. After that, the nazirite may drink wine.

Chapter 6.6:21: These are the regulations for you nazirites; but if you promise an offering beyond what your vow requires you to give, you must fulfill exactly the promise you made.

Chapter 6.6:23: to tell Aaron and his sons to use the following words in blessing the people of Israel:

Chapter 6.6:24: May the Lord bless you and take care of you;

Chapter 6.6:25: May the Lord be kind and gracious to you;

Chapter 6.6:26: May the Lord look on you with favor and give you peace.

Chapter 6.6:27: And the Lord said, If they pronounce my name as a blessing upon the people of Israel, I will bless them.

Chapter 8.8:2: Tell Aaron that when he puts the seven lamps on the lampstand, he should place them so that the light shines toward the front.

Chapter 8.8:6: Separate the Levites from the rest of the people of Israel and purify them

Chapter 8.8:7: in the following way: sprinkle them with the water of purification and have them shave their whole bodies and have them wash their clothes. Then they will be ritually clean.

Chapter 8.8:8: Then they are to take a young bull and the required grain offering of flour mixed with olive oil; and you are to take another bull for the sin offering.

Chapter 8.8:9: Then assemble the whole community of Israel and have the Levites stand in front of the Tent of my presence.

Chapter 8.8:10: The people of Israel are to place their hands on the heads of the Levites,

Chapter 8.8:11: and then Aaron shall dedicate the Levites to me as a special gift from the Israelites, so that they may do my work.

Chapter 8.8:12: The Levites shall then put their hands on the heads of the two bulls; one is to be offered as a sin offering and the other as a burnt offering, in order to perform the ritual of purification for the Levites.

Chapter 8.8:13: Dedicate the Levites as a special gift to me, and put Aaron and his sons in charge of them.

Chapter 8.8:14: Separate the Levites in this way from the rest of the Israelites, so that they will belong to me.

Chapter 8.8:15: After you have purified and dedicated the Levites, they will be qualified to work in the Tent.

Chapter 8.8:16: I have claimed them in the place of all the first-born sons of the Israelites, and they belong to me alone.

Chapter 8.8:17: When I killed all the first-born in Egypt, I consecrated as my own the oldest son of each Israelite family and the first-born of every animal.

Chapter 8.8:18: I am now taking the Levites instead of all the first-born of the Israelites,

Chapter 8.8:19: and I assign the Levites to Aaron and his sons, as a gift from the Israelites, to work in the Tent for the people of Israel and to protect the Israelites from the disaster that would strike them if they came too near the Holy Place.

Chapter 8.8:20: So Moses, Aaron, and all the people of Israel dedicated the Levites, as the Lord commanded Moses.

Chapter 8.8:21: The Levites purified themselves and washed their clothes, and Aaron dedicated them as a special gift to the Lord. He also performed the ritual of purification for them.

Chapter 8.8:22: The people did everything the Lord had commanded Moses concerning the Levites. And so the Levites were qualified to work in the Tent under Aaron and his sons.

Chapter 8.8:24: From the age of twenty-five each Levite shall perform his duties in the Tent of my presence,

Chapter 8.8:25: and at the age of fifty he shall retire.

Chapter 8.8:26: After that, he may help his fellow Levites in performing their duties in the Tent, but he must not perform any service by himself. This is how you are to regulate the duties of the Levites.

Chapter 9.9:1: The Lord spoke to Moses in the Sinai Desert in the first month of the second year after the people of Israel had left Egypt. He said,

Chapter 9.9:2: On the fourteenth day of this month, beginning at sunset, the people of Israel are to observe the Passover according to all the rules and regulations for it.

Chapter 9.9:3: On the fourteenth day of this month, beginning at sunset, the people of Israel are to observe the Passover according to all the rules and regulations for it.

Chapter 9.9:4: So Moses told the people to observe the Passover,

Chapter 9.9:5: and on the evening of the fourteenth day of the first month they did so in the Sinai Desert. The people did everything just as the Lord had commanded Moses.

Chapter 9.9:6: But there were some people who were ritually unclean because they had touched a corpse, and they were not able to keep the Passover on that day. They went to Moses and Aaron

Chapter 9.9:7: and said, We are unclean because we have touched a corpse, but why should we be excluded from presenting the Lord's offering with the rest of the Israelites?

Chapter 9.9:8: Moses answered, Wait until I receive instructions from the Lord.

Chapter 9.9:10: to say to the people of Israel, When any of you or your descendants are unclean from touching a corpse or are far away on a journey, but still want to keep the Passover,

Chapter 9.9:11: you are permitted to observe it one month later instead, on the evening of the fourteenth day of the second month. Celebrate it with unleavened bread and bitter herbs.

Chapter 9.9:12: Do not leave any of the food until the following morning and do not break any of the animal's bones. Observe the Passover according to all the regulations.

Chapter 9.9:13: But if any of you are ritually clean and not away on a journey and do not observe the Passover, you shall no longer be considered my people, because you did not present the offering to me at the appointed time. You must suffer the consequences of your sin.

Chapter 9.9:14: If foreigners living among you want to keep the Passover, they must observe it according to all the rules and regulations. The same law applies to everyone, whether native or foreigner.

Chapter 9.9:15: On the day the Tent of the Lord's presence was set up, a cloud came and covered it. At night the cloud looked like fire.

Chapter 9.9:16: On the day the Tent of the Lord's presence was set up, a cloud came and covered it. At night the cloud looked like fire.

Chapter 9.9:17: Whenever the cloud lifted, the people of Israel broke camp, and they set up camp again in the place where the cloud came down.

Chapter 9.9:18: The people broke camp at the command of the Lord, and at his command they set up camp. As long as the cloud stayed over the Tent, they stayed in the same camp.

Chapter 9.9:19: When the cloud stayed over the Tent for a long time, they obeyed the Lord and did not move on.

Chapter 9.9:20: Sometimes the cloud remained over the Tent for only a few days; in any case, they remained in camp or moved, according to the command of the Lord.

Chapter 9.9:21: Sometimes the cloud remained only from evening until morning, and they moved on as soon as the cloud lifted. Whenever the cloud lifted, they moved on.

Chapter 9.9:22: Whether it was two days, a month, a year, or longer, as long as the cloud remained over the Tent, they did not move on; but when it lifted, they moved.

Chapter 9.9:23: They set up camp and broke camp in obedience to the commands which the Lord gave through Moses.

Chapter 10.10:2: Make two trumpets of hammered silver to use for calling the people together and for breaking camp.

Chapter 10.10:3: When long blasts are sounded on both trumpets, the whole community is to gather around you at the entrance to the Tent of my presence.

Chapter 10.10:4: But when only one trumpet is sounded, then only the leaders of the clans are to gather around you.

Chapter 10.10:5: When short blasts are sounded, the tribes camped on the east will move out.

Chapter 10.10:6: When short blasts are sounded a second time, the tribes on the south will move out. So short blasts are to be sounded to break camp,

Chapter 10.10:7: but in order to call the community together, long blasts are to be sounded.

Chapter 10.10:8: The trumpets are to be blown by Aaron's sons, the priests. The following rule is to be observed for all time to come.

Chapter 10.10:9: When you are at war in your land, defending yourselves against an enemy who has attacked you, sound the signal for battle on these trumpets. I, the Lord your God, will help you and save you from your enemies.

Chapter 10.10:10: Also on joyful occasions—at your New Moon Festivals and your other religious festivals—you are to blow the trumpets when you present your burnt offerings and your fellowship offerings. Then I will help you. I am the Lord your God.

Chapter 10.10:11: On the twentieth day of the second month in the second year after the people left Egypt, the cloud over the Tent of the Lord's presence lifted,

Chapter 10.10:12: and the Israelites started on their journey out of the Sinai Desert. The cloud came to rest in the wilderness of Paran.

Chapter 10.10:13: They began to march at the command of the Lord through Moses,

Chapter 10.10:14: and each time they moved, they were in the same order. Those under the banner of the division led by the tribe of Judah started out first, company by company, with Nahshon son of Amminadab in command.

Chapter 10.10:15: Nethanel son of Zuar was in command of the tribe of Issachar,

Chapter 10.10:16: and Eliab son of Helon was in command of the tribe of Zebulun.

Chapter 10.10:17: Then the Tent would be taken down, and the clans of Gershon and Merari, who carried it, would start out.

Chapter 10.10:18: Next, those under the banner of the division led by the tribe of Reuben would start out, company by company, with Elizur son of Shedeur in command.

Chapter 10.10:19: Shelumiel son of Zurishaddai was in command of the tribe of Simeon,

Chapter 10.10:20: and Eliasaph son of Deuel was in command of the tribe of Gad.

Chapter 10.10:21: Then the Levite clan of Kohath would start out, carrying the sacred objects. By the time they arrived at the next camp, the Tent had been set up again.

Chapter 10.10:22: Next, those under the banner of the division led by the tribe of Ephraim would start out, company by company, with Elishama son of Ammihud in command.

Chapter 10.10:23: Gamaliel son of Pedahzur was in command of the tribe of Manasseh,

Chapter 10.10:24: and Abidan son of Gideoni was in command of the tribe of Benjamin.

Chapter 10.10:25: Finally, those under the banner of the division led by the tribe of Dan, serving as the rear guard of all the divisions, would start out, company by company, with Ahiezer son of Ammishaddai in command.

Chapter 10.10:26: Pagiel son of Ochran was in command of the tribe of Asher,

Chapter 10.10:27: and Ahira son of Enan was in command of the tribe of Naphtali.

Chapter 10.10:28: This, then, was the order of march, company by company, whenever the Israelites broke camp and set out.

Chapter 10.10:29: Moses said to his brother-in-law Hobab son of Jethro the Midianite, We are about to start out for the place which the Lord said he would give us. He has promised to make Israel prosperous, so come with us, and we will share our prosperity with you.

Chapter 10.10:30: Hobab answered, No, I am going back to my native land.

Chapter 10.10:31: Please don't leave us, Moses said. You know where we can camp in the wilderness, and you can be our guide.

Chapter 10.10:32: If you come with us, we will share with you all the blessings that the Lord gives us.

Chapter 10.10:33: When the people left Sinai, the holy mountain, they traveled three days. The Lord's Covenant Box always went ahead of them to find a place for them to camp.

Chapter 10.10:34: As they moved on from each camp, the cloud of the Lord was over them by day.

Chapter 10.10:35: Whenever the Covenant Box started out, Moses would say, Arise, Lord; scatter your enemies and put to flight those who hate you!

Chapter 10.10:36: And whenever it stopped, he would say, Return, Lord, to the thousands of families of Israel.

Chapter 11.11:1: The people began to complain to the Lord about their troubles. When the Lord heard them, he became angry and sent fire on the people. It burned among them and destroyed one end of the camp.

Chapter 11.11:2: The people cried out to Moses for help; he prayed to the Lord, and the fire died down.

Chapter 11.11:3: So the place was named Taberah, because there the fire of the Lord burned among them.

Chapter 11.11:4: There were foreigners traveling with the Israelites. They had a strong craving for meat, and even the Israelites themselves began to complain: If only we could have some meat!

Chapter 11.11:5: In Egypt we used to eat all the fish we wanted, and it cost us nothing. Remember the cucumbers, the watermelons, the leeks, the onions, and the garlic we had?

Chapter 11.11:6: But now our strength is gone. There is nothing at all to eat—nothing but this manna day after day!

Chapter 11.11:7: Manna was like small seeds, whitish yellow in color.

Chapter 11.11:8: It fell on the camp at night along with the dew. The next morning the people would go around and gather it, grind it or pound it into flour, and then boil it and make it into flat cakes. It tasted like bread baked with olive oil.

Chapter 11.11:9: It fell on the camp at night along with the dew. The next morning the people would go around and gather it, grind it or pound it into flour, and then boil it and make it into flat cakes. It tasted like bread baked with olive oil.

Chapter 11.11:10: Moses heard all the people complaining as they stood around in groups at the entrances of their tents. He was distressed because the Lord had become angry with them,

Chapter 11.11:11: and he said to the Lord, Why have you treated me so badly? Why are you displeased with me? Why have you given me the responsibility for all these people?

Chapter 11.11:12: I didn't create them or bring them to birth! Why should you ask me to act like a nurse and carry them in my arms like babies all the way to the land you promised to their ancestors?

Chapter 11.11:13: Where could I get enough meat for all these people? They keep whining and asking for meat.

Chapter 11.11:14: I can't be responsible for all these people by myself; it's too much for me!

Chapter 11.11:15: If you are going to treat me like this, have pity on me and kill me, so that I won't have to endure your cruelty any longer.

Chapter 11.11:16: The Lord said to Moses, Assemble seventy respected men who are recognized as leaders of the people, bring them to me at the Tent of my presence, and tell them to stand there beside you.

Chapter 11.11:17: I will come down and speak with you there, and I will take some of the spirit I have given you and give it to them. Then they can help you bear the responsibility for these people, and you will not have to bear it alone.

Chapter 11.11:18: Now tell the people, Purify yourselves for tomorrow; you will have meat to eat. The Lord has heard you whining and saying that you wished you had some meat and that you were better off in Egypt. Now the Lord will give you meat, and you will have to eat it.

Chapter 11.11:19: You will have to eat it not just for one or two days, or five, or ten, or even twenty days,

Chapter 18.18:7: But you and your sons alone shall fulfill all the responsibilities of the priesthood that concern the altar and what is in the Most Holy Place. These things are your responsibility, because I have given you the gift of the priesthood. Any unqualified person who comes near the sacred objects shall be put to death.

Chapter 18.18:8: The Lord said to Aaron, Remember that I am giving you all the special contributions made to me that are not burned as sacrifices. I am giving them to you and to your descendants as the part assigned to you forever.

Chapter 18.18:9: Of the most sacred offerings not burned on the altar, the following belong to you: the grain offerings, the sin offerings, and the repayment offerings. Everything that is presented to me as a sacred offering belongs to you and your sons.

Chapter 18.18:10: You must eat these things in a holy place, and only males may eat them; consider them holy.

Chapter 18.18:11: In addition, any other special contributions that the Israelites present to me shall be yours. I am giving them to you, your sons, and your daughters for all time to come. Every member of your family who is ritually clean may eat them.

Chapter 18.18:12: I am giving you all the best of the first produce which the Israelites give me each year: olive oil, wine, and grain.

Chapter 18.18:13: It all belongs to you. Every member of your family who is ritually clean may eat it.

Chapter 18.18:14: Everything in Israel that has been unconditionally dedicated to me belongs to you.

Chapter 18.18:15: Every first-born child or animal that the Israelites present to me belongs to you. But you must accept payment to buy back every first-born child, and must also accept payment for every first-born animal that is ritually unclean.

Chapter 18.18:16: Children shall be bought back at the age of one month for the fixed price of five pieces of silver, according to the official standard.

Chapter 18.18:17: But the first-born of cows, sheep, and goats are not to be bought back; they belong completely to me and are to be sacrificed. Throw their blood against the altar and burn their fat as a food offering, an odor pleasing to me.

Chapter 18.18:18: The meat from them belongs to you, like the breast and the right hind leg of the special offering.

Chapter 18.18:19: I am giving to you, to your sons, and to your daughters, for all time to come, all the special contributions which the Israelites present to me. This is an unbreakable covenant that I have made with you and your descendants.

Chapter 18.18:20: The Lord said to Aaron, You will not receive any property that can be inherited, and no part of the land of Israel will be assigned to you. I, the Lord, am all you need.

Chapter 18.18:21: The Lord said, I have given to the Levites every tithe that the people of Israel present to me. This is in payment for their service in taking care of the Tent of my presence.

Chapter 18.18:22: The other Israelites must no longer approach the Tent and in this way bring on themselves the penalty of death.

Chapter 18.18:23: From now on only the Levites will take care of the Tent and bear the full responsibility for it. This is a permanent rule that applies also to your descendants. The Levites shall have no permanent property in Israel,

Chapter 18.18:24: because I have given to them as their possession the tithe which the Israelites present to me as a special contribution. That is why I told them that they would have no permanent property in Israel.

Chapter 18.18:26: to say to the Levites: When you receive from the Israelites the tithe that the Lord gives you as your possession, you must present a tenth of it as a special contribution to the Lord.

Chapter 18.18:27: This special contribution will be considered as the equivalent of the offering which the farmer makes of new grain and new wine.

Chapter 18.18:28: In this way you also will present the special contribution that belongs to the Lord from all the tithes which you receive from the Israelites. You are to give this special contribution for the Lord to Aaron the priest.

Chapter 18.18:29: Give it from the best that you receive.

Chapter 18.18:30: When you have presented the best part, you may keep the rest, just as the farmer keeps what is left after he makes his offering.

Chapter 18.18:31: You and your families may eat the rest anywhere, because it is your wages for your service in the Tent.

Chapter 18.18:32: You will not become guilty when you eat it, as long as you have presented the best of it to the Lord. But be sure not to profane the sacred gifts of the Israelites by eating any of the gifts before the best part is offered; if you do, you will be put to death.

Chapter 19.19:1: The Lord commanded Moses and Aaron

Chapter 19.19:2: to give the Israelites the following regulations. Bring to Moses and Aaron a red cow which has no defects and which has never been worked,

Chapter 19.19:3: and they will give it to Eleazar the priest. It is to be taken outside the camp and killed in his presence.

Chapter 19.19:4: Then Eleazar is to take some of its blood and with his finger sprinkle it seven times in the direction of the Tent.

Chapter 19.19:5: The whole animal, including skin, meat, blood, and intestines, is to be burned in the presence of the priest.

Chapter 19.19:6: Then he is to take some cedar wood, a sprig of hyssop, and a red cord and throw them into the fire.

Chapter 19.19:7: After that, he is to wash his clothes and pour water over himself, and then he may enter the camp; but he remains ritually unclean until evening.

Chapter 19.19:8: The one who burned the cow must also wash his clothes and pour water over himself, but he also remains unclean until evening.

Chapter 19.19:9: Then someone who is ritually clean is to collect the ashes of the cow and put them in a ritually clean place outside the camp, where they are to be kept for the Israelite community to use in preparing the water for removing ritual uncleanness. This ritual is performed to remove sin.

Chapter 19.19:10: The one who collected the ashes must wash his clothes, but he remains unclean until evening. This regulation is valid for all time to come, both for the Israelites and for the foreigners living among them.

Chapter 19.19:11: Those who touch a corpse are ritually unclean for seven days.

Chapter 19.19:12: They must purify themselves with the water for purification on the third day and on the seventh day, and then they will be clean. But if they do not purify themselves on both the third and the seventh day, they will not be clean.

Chapter 19.19:13: Those who touch a corpse and do not purify themselves remain unclean, because the water for purification has not been thrown over them. They defile the Lord's Tent, and they will no longer be considered God's people.

Chapter 19.19:14: In the case of a person who dies in a tent, anyone who is in the tent at the time of death or who enters it becomes ritually unclean for seven days.

Chapter 19.19:15: Every jar and pot in the tent that has no lid on it also becomes unclean.

Chapter 19.19:16: If any touch a person who has been killed or has died a natural death outdoors or if any touch a human bone or a grave, they become unclean for seven days.

Chapter 19.19:17: To remove the uncleanness, some ashes from the red cow which was burned to remove sin shall be taken and put in a pot, and fresh water added.

Chapter 19.19:18: In the first case, someone who is ritually clean is to take a sprig of hyssop, dip it in the water, and sprinkle the tent, everything in it, and the people who were there. In the second case, someone who is ritually clean is to sprinkle the water on those who had touched the human bone or the dead body or the grave.

Chapter 19.19:19: On the third day and on the seventh the person who is ritually clean is to sprinkle the water on the unclean persons. On the seventh day he is to purify those, who, after washing their clothes and pouring water over themselves, become ritually clean at sunset.

Chapter 19.19:20: Those who have become ritually unclean and do not purify themselves remain unclean, because the water for purification has not been thrown over them. They defile the Lord's Tent and will no longer be considered God's people.

Chapter 19.19:21: You are to observe this rule for all time to come. The person who sprinkles the water for purification must also wash his clothes; anyone who touches the water remains ritually unclean until evening.

Chapter 19.19:22: Whatever an unclean person touches is unclean, and anyone else who touches it remains unclean until evening.

Chapter 20.20:1: In the first month the whole community of Israel came to the wilderness of Zin and camped at Kadesh. There Miriam died and was buried.

Chapter 20.20:2: There was no water where they camped, so the people gathered around Moses and Aaron

Chapter 20.20:3: and complained: It would have been better if we had died in front of the Lord's Tent along with the other Israelites.

Chapter 20.20:4: Why have you brought us out into this wilderness? Just so that we can die here with our animals?

Chapter 20.20:5: Why did you bring us out of Egypt into this miserable place where nothing will grow? There's no grain, no figs, no grapes, no pomegranates. There is not even any water to drink!

Chapter 20.20:6: Moses and Aaron moved away from the people and stood at the entrance of the Tent. They bowed down with their faces to the ground, and the dazzling light of the Lord's presence appeared to them.

Chapter 20.20:8: Take the stick that is in front of the Covenant Box, and then you and Aaron assemble the whole community. There in front of them all speak to that rock over there, and water will gush out of it. In this way you will bring water out of the rock for the people, for them and their animals to drink.

Chapter 20.20:9: Moses went and got the stick, as the Lord had commanded.

Chapter 20.20:10: He and Aaron assembled the whole community in front of the rock, and Moses said, Listen, you rebels! Do we have to get water out of this rock for you?

Chapter 20.20:11: Then Moses raised the stick and struck the rock twice with it, and a great stream of water gushed out, and all the people and animals drank.

Chapter 20.20:12: But the Lord reprimanded Moses and Aaron. He said, Because you did not have enough faith to acknowledge my holy power before the people of Israel, you will not lead them into the land that I promised to give them.

Chapter 20.20:13: This happened at Meribah, where the people of Israel complained against the Lord and where he showed them that he is holy.

Chapter 20.20:14: Moses sent messengers from Kadesh to the king of Edom. They said, This message is from your kinsmen, the tribes of Israel. You know the hardships we have suffered,

Chapter 20.20:15: how our ancestors went to Egypt, where we lived many years. The Egyptians mistreated our ancestors and us,

Chapter 20.20:16: and we cried to the Lord for help. He heard our cry and sent an angel, who led us out of Egypt. Now we are at Kadesh, a town at the border of your territory.

Chapter 20.20:17: Please permit us to pass through your land. We and our cattle will not leave the road or go into your fields or vineyards, and we will not drink from your wells. We will stay on the main road until we are out of your territory.

Chapter 20.20:18: But the Edomites answered, We refuse to let you pass through our country! If you try, we will march out and attack you.

Chapter 20.20:19: The people of Israel said, We will stay on the main road, and if we or our animals drink any of your water, we will pay for it—all we want is to pass through.

Chapter 20.20:20: The Edomites repeated, We refuse! and they marched out with a powerful army to attack the people of Israel.

Chapter 20.20:21: Because the Edomites would not let the Israelites pass through their territory, the Israelites turned and went another way.

Chapter 20.20:22: The whole community of Israel left Kadesh and arrived at Mount Hor,

Chapter 20.20:23: on the border of Edom. There the Lord said to Moses and Aaron,

Chapter 20.20:24: Aaron is not going to enter the land which I promised to give to Israel; he is going to die, because the two of you rebelled against my command at Meribah.

Chapter 20.20:25: Take Aaron and his son Eleazar up Mount Hor,

Chapter 20.20:26: and there remove Aaron's priestly robes and put them on Eleazar. Aaron is going to die there.

Chapter 20.20:27: Moses did what the Lord had commanded. They went up Mount Hor in the sight of the whole community,

Chapter 20.20:28: and Moses removed Aaron's priestly robes and put them on Eleazar. There on the top of the mountain Aaron died, and Moses and Eleazar came back down.

Chapter 20.20:29: The whole community learned that Aaron had died, and they all mourned for him for thirty days.

Chapter 21.21:1: When the Canaanite king of Arad in the southern part of Canaan heard that the Israelites were coming by way of Atharim, he attacked them and captured some of them.

Chapter 21.21:2: Then the Israelites made a vow to the Lord: If you will let us conquer these people, we will unconditionally dedicate them and their cities to you and will destroy them.

Chapter 21.21:3: The Lord heard them and helped them conquer the Canaanites. So the Israelites completely destroyed them and their cities, and named the place Hormah.

Chapter 21.21:4: The Israelites left Mount Hor by the road that leads to the Gulf of Aqaba, in order to go around the territory of Edom. But on the way the people lost their patience

Chapter 21.21:5: and spoke against God and Moses. They complained, Why did you bring us out of Egypt to die in this desert, where there is no food or water? We can't stand any more of this miserable food!

Chapter 21.21:6: Then the Lord sent poisonous snakes among the people, and many Israelites were bitten and died.

Chapter 21.21:7: The people came to Moses and said, We sinned when we spoke against the Lord and against you. Now pray to the Lord to take these snakes away. So Moses prayed for the people.

Chapter 21.21:8: Then the Lord told Moses to make a metal snake and put it on a pole, so that anyone who was bitten could look at it and be healed.

Chapter 21.21:10: The Israelites moved on and camped at Oboth.

Chapter 21.21:11: After leaving that place, they camped at the ruins of Abarim in the wilderness east of Moabite territory.

Chapter 21.21:12: Then they camped in Zered Valley.

Chapter 21.21:13: From there they moved again and camped on the north side of the Arnon River, in the wilderness which extends into Amorite territory. The Arnon was the border between the Moabites and the Amorites.

Chapter 21.21:14: That is why The Book of the Lord's Battles speaks of … the town of Waheb in the area of Suphah, and the valleys; the Arnon River,

Chapter 21.21:15: and the slope of the valleys that extend to the town of Ar and toward the border of Moab.

Chapter 21.21:16: From there they went on to a place called Wells, where the Lord said to Moses, Bring the people together, and I will give them water.

Chapter 21.21:17: At that time the people of Israel sang this song: Wells, produce your water; And we will greet it with a song—

Chapter 21.21:18: The well dug by princes And by leaders of the people, Dug with a royal scepter And with their walking sticks. They moved from the wilderness to Mattanah,

Chapter 21.21:19: and from there they went on to Nahaliel, and from Nahaliel to Bamoth,

Chapter 21.21:20: and from Bamoth to the valley in the territory of the Moabites, below the top of Mount Pisgah, looking out over the desert.

Chapter 21.21:21: Then the people of Israel sent messengers to the Amorite king Sihon to say:

Chapter 21.21:22: Let us pass through your land. We and our cattle will not leave the road and go into your fields or vineyards, and we will not drink water from your wells; we will stay on the main road until we are out of your territory.

Chapter 21.21:23: But Sihon would not permit the people of Israel to pass through his territory. He gathered his army and went out to Jahaz in the wilderness and attacked the Israelites.

Chapter 21.21:24: But the Israelites killed many of the enemy in battle and occupied their land from the Arnon River north to the Jabbok, that is, to the Ammonites, because the Ammonite border was strongly defended.

Chapter 21.21:25: So the people of Israel captured all the Amorite cities, including Heshbon and all the surrounding towns, and settled in them.

Chapter 21.21:26: Heshbon was the capital city of the Amorite king Sihon, who had fought against the former king of Moab and had captured all his land as far as the Arnon River.

Chapter 21.21:27: That is why the poets sing, Come to Heshbon, to King Sihon's city! We want to see it rebuilt and restored.

Chapter 21.21:28: Once from this city of Heshbon Sihon's army went forth like a fire; It destroyed the city of Ar in Moab And devoured the hills of the upper Arnon.

Chapter 21.21:29: How terrible for you, people of Moab! You worshipers of Chemosh are brought to ruin! Your god let the men become refugees, And the women became captives of the Amorite king.

Chapter 21.21:30: But now their descendants are destroyed, All the way from Heshbon to Dibon, From Nashim to Nophah, near Medeba.

Chapter 21.21:31: So the people of Israel settled in the territory of the Amorites,

Chapter 21.21:32: and Moses sent men to find the best way to attack the city of Jazer. The Israelites captured it and its surrounding towns and drove out the Amorites living there.

Chapter 21.21:33: Then the Israelites turned and took the road to Bashan, and King Og of Bashan marched out with his army to attack them at Edrei.

Chapter 21.21:34: The Lord said to Moses, Do not be afraid of him. I will give you victory over him, all his people, and his land. Do to him what you did to Sihon, the Amorite king who ruled at Heshbon.

Chapter 21.21:35: So the Israelites killed Og, his sons, and all his people, leaving no survivors, and then they occupied his land.

Chapter 22.22:1: The Israelites moved on and set up camp in the plains of Moab east of the Jordan and opposite Jericho.

Chapter 22.22:3: he and all his people became terrified.

Chapter 22.22:5: sent messengers to summon Balaam son of Beor, who was at Pethor near the Euphrates River in the land of Amaw. They brought him this message from Balak: I want you to know that a whole nation has come from Egypt; its people are spreading out everywhere and threatening to take over our land.

Chapter 22.22:6: They outnumber us, so please come and put a curse on them for me. Then perhaps we will be able to defeat them and drive them out of the land. I know that when you pronounce a blessing, people are blessed, and when you pronounce a curse, they are placed under a curse.

Chapter 22.22:16: They went to Balaam and gave him this message from Balak: Please don't let anything prevent you from coming to me!

Chapter 22.22:17: I will reward you richly and do anything you say. Please come and curse these people for me.

Chapter 22.22:18: But Balaam answered, Even if Balak gave me all the silver and gold in his palace, I could not disobey the command of the Lord my God in even the smallest matter.

Chapter 22.22:19: But please spend the night, as the others did, so that I may learn whether or not the Lord has something else to tell me.

Chapter 22.22:20: That night God came to Balaam and said, If these men have come to ask you to go with them, get ready and go, but do only what I tell you.

Chapter 22.22:22: God was angry that Balaam was going, and as Balaam was riding along on his donkey, accompanied by his two servants, the angel of the Lord stood in the road to bar his way.

Chapter 22.22:23: When the donkey saw the angel standing there holding a sword, it left the road and turned into the fields. Balaam beat the donkey and brought it back onto the road.

Chapter 22.22:24: Then the angel stood where the road narrowed between two vineyards and had a stone wall on each side.

Chapter 22.22:25: When the donkey saw the angel, it moved over against the wall and crushed Balaam's foot against it. Again Balaam beat the donkey.

Chapter 22.22:26: Once more the angel moved ahead; he stood in a narrow place where there was no room at all to pass on either side.

Chapter 22.22:27: This time, when the donkey saw the angel, it lay down. Balaam lost his temper and began to beat the donkey with his stick.

Chapter 22.22:28: Then the Lord gave the donkey the power of speech, and it said to Balaam, What have I done to you? Why have you beaten me these three times?

Chapter 22.22:29: Balaam answered, Because you have made a fool of me! If I had a sword, I would kill you.

Chapter 22.22:30: The donkey replied, Am I not the same donkey on which you have ridden all your life? Have I ever treated you like this before? No, he answered.

Chapter 22.22:31: Then the Lord let Balaam see the angel standing there with his sword; and Balaam threw himself face downward on the ground.

Chapter 22.22:33: But your donkey saw me and turned aside three times. If it hadn't, I would have killed you and spared the donkey.

Chapter 22.22:35: But the angel said, Go on with these men, but say only what I tell you to say. So Balaam went on with them.

Chapter 22.22:39: So Balaam went with Balak to the town of Huzoth,

Chapter 23.23:1: He said to Balak, Build seven altars here for me, and bring me seven bulls and seven rams.

Chapter 23.23:19: God is not like people, who lie; He is not a human who changes his mind. Whatever he promises, he does; He speaks, and it is done.

Chapter 27.27:1: Mahlah, Noah, Hoglah, Milcah, and Tirzah were the daughters of Zelophehad son of Hepher, son of Gilead, son of Machir, son of Manasseh, son of Joseph.

Chapter 27.27:2: They went and stood before Moses, Eleazar the priest, the leaders, and the whole community at the entrance of the Tent of the Lord's presence and said,

Chapter 27.27:5: Moses presented their case to the Lord,

Chapter 27.27:6: and the Lord said to him,

Chapter 27.27:7: What the daughters of Zelophehad request is right; give them property among their father's relatives. Let his inheritance pass on to them.

Chapter 27.27:8: Tell the people of Israel that whenever a man dies without leaving a son, his daughter is to inherit his property.

Chapter 27.27:9: If he has no daughter, his brothers are to inherit it.

Chapter 27.27:10: If he has no brothers, his father's brothers are to inherit it.

Chapter 27.27:11: If he has no brothers or uncles, then his nearest relative is to inherit it and hold it as his own property. The people of Israel are to observe this as a legal requirement, just as I, the Lord, have commanded you.

Chapter 27.27:12: The Lord said to Moses, Go up the Abarim Mountains and look out over the land that I am giving to the Israelites.

Chapter 27.27:13: After you have seen it, you will die, as your brother Aaron did,

Chapter 27.27:17: and can command them in battle, so that your community will not be like sheep without a shepherd.

Chapter 27.27:18: The Lord said to Moses, Take Joshua son of Nun, a capable man, and place your hands on his head.

Chapter 27.27:19: Have him stand in front of Eleazar the priest and the whole community, and there before them all proclaim him as your successor.

Chapter 27.27:20: Give him some of your own authority, so that the whole community of Israel will obey him.

Chapter 27.27:22: Moses did as the Lord had commanded him. He had Joshua stand before Eleazar the priest and the whole community.

Chapter 27.27:23: As the Lord had commanded, Moses put his hands on Joshua's head and proclaimed him as his successor.

Chapter 30.30:1: Moses gave the following instructions to the leaders of the tribes of Israel.

Chapter 30.30:2: When a man makes a vow to give something to the Lord or takes an oath to abstain from something, he must not break his promise, but must do everything that he said he would.

Chapter 30.30:3: When a young woman still living in her father's house makes a vow to give something to the Lord or promises to abstain from something,

Chapter 30.30:4: she must do everything that she vowed or promised unless her father raises an objection when he hears about it.

Chapter 30.30:5: But if her father forbids her to fulfill the vow when he hears about it, she is not required to keep it. The Lord will forgive her, because her father refused to let her keep it.

Chapter 30.30:6: If an unmarried woman makes a vow, whether deliberately or carelessly, or promises to abstain from something, and then marries,

Chapter 30.30:7: she must do everything that she vowed or promised unless her husband raises an objection when he hears about it.

Chapter 30.30:8: But if her husband forbids her to fulfill the vow when he hears about it, she is not required to keep it. The Lord will forgive her.

Chapter 30.30:9: A widow or a divorced woman must keep every vow she makes and every promise to abstain from something.

Chapter 30.30:10: If a married woman makes a vow or promises to abstain from something,

Chapter 30.30:11: she must do everything that she vowed or promised unless her husband raises an objection when he hears about it.

Chapter 30.30:12: But if her husband forbids her to fulfill the vow when he hears about it, she is not required to keep it. The Lord will forgive her, because her husband prevented her from keeping her vow.

Chapter 30.30:13: Her husband has the right to affirm or to annul any vow or promise that she has made.

Chapter 30.30:14: But if, by the day after he hears of the vow, he has raised no objection, she must do everything that she has vowed or promised. He has affirmed the vow by not objecting on the day he heard of it.

Chapter 30.30:15: But if he later annuls the vow, he must suffer the consequences for the failure to fulfill the vow.

Chapter 30.30:16: These are the rules that the Lord gave Moses concerning vows made by an unmarried woman living in her father's house or by a married woman.

Chapter 31.31:50: So we are bringing the gold ornaments, armlets, bracelets, rings, earrings, and necklaces that each of us has taken. We offer them to the Lord as a payment for our lives, so that he will protect us.

Chapter 31.31:51: Moses and Eleazar received the gold, all of which was in the form of ornaments.

Chapter 31.31:52: The total contribution of the officers weighed over four hundred pounds.

Chapter 31.31:53: Those who were not officers kept the loot they had taken.

Chapter 31.31:54: So Moses and Eleazar took the gold to the Tent, so that the Lord would protect the people of Israel.

Chapter 32.32:1: The tribes of Reuben and Gad had a lot of livestock. When they saw how suitable the land of Jazer and Gilead was for cattle,

Chapter 32.32:2: they went to Moses, Eleazar, and the other leaders of the community and said,

Chapter 32.32:3: This region which the Lord has helped the Israelites occupy—the towns of Ataroth, Dibon, Jazer, Nimrah, Heshbon, Elealeh, Sibmah, Nebo, and Beon—is good land for livestock, and we have so much livestock.

Chapter 32.32:4: This region which the Lord has helped the Israelites occupy—the towns of Ataroth, Dibon, Jazer, Nimrah, Heshbon, Elealeh, Sibmah, Nebo, and Beon—is good land for livestock, and we have so much livestock.

Chapter 32.32:5: Please give us this land as our property, and do not make us cross the Jordan River and settle there.

Chapter 32.32:6: Moses replied, Do you want to stay here while the other Israelites go to war?

Chapter 32.32:7: How dare you try to discourage the people of Israel from crossing the Jordan into the land which the Lord has given them?

Chapter 32.32:8: That is what your fathers did when I sent them from Kadesh Barnea to explore the land.

Chapter 32.32:9: They went as far as Eshcol Valley and saw the land, but when they returned, they discouraged the people from entering the land which the Lord had given them.

Chapter 32.32:10: The Lord became angry that day and made a promise:

Chapter 32.32:11: I swear that because they did not remain loyal to me, none of the men twenty years old or older who came out of Egypt will enter the land that I promised to Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob.

Chapter 32.32:12: This included everyone, except Caleb son of Jephunneh the Kenizzite and Joshua son of Nun; they remained loyal to the Lord.

Chapter 32.32:13: The Lord became angry with the people and made them wander in the wilderness forty years until that whole generation that had displeased him was dead.

Chapter 32.32:14: And now you have taken your ancestors' place, a new generation of sinful people ready to bring down the fierce anger of the Lord on Israel again.

Chapter 32.32:15: If you people of Reuben and Gad refuse to follow him now, he will once again abandon all these people in the wilderness, and you will be responsible for their destruction.

Chapter 32.32:16: They approached Moses and said, First, allow us to build stone enclosures here for our sheep and fortified towns for our dependents.

Chapter 32.32:17: Then we will be ready to go with the other Israelites into battle and lead the attack until we have settled them in the land that will be theirs. In the meantime, our dependents can live here in the fortified towns, safe from the people of this land.

Chapter 32.32:18: We will not return to our homes until all the other Israelites have taken possession of the land assigned to them.

Chapter 32.32:19: We will not take possession of any property among them on the other side of the Jordan, because we have received our share here east of the Jordan.

Chapter 32.32:20: Moses answered, If you really mean what you say, then here in the presence of the Lord get ready to go into battle.

Chapter 32.32:21: All your fighting men are to cross the Jordan and under the command of the Lord they are to attack our enemies until the Lord defeats them

Chapter 32.32:22: and takes possession of the land. After that, you may return, because you will have fulfilled your obligation to the Lord and to the other Israelites. Then the Lord will acknowledge that this land east of the Jordan is yours.

Chapter 32.32:23: But if you do not keep your promise, I warn you that you will be sinning against the Lord. Make no mistake about it; you will be punished for your sin.

Chapter 32.32:24: So build your towns and the enclosures for your sheep, but do what you have promised!

Chapter 32.32:25: The men of Gad and Reuben said, Sir, we will do as you command.

Chapter 32.32:26: Our wives and children and our cattle and sheep will remain here in the towns of Gilead.

Chapter 32.32:27: But all of us are ready to go into battle under the Lord's command. We will cross the Jordan and fight, just as you have said.

Chapter 32.32:28: So Moses gave these commands to Eleazar, Joshua, and the other leaders of Israel:

Chapter 32.32:29: If the men of Gad and Reuben cross the Jordan ready for battle at the Lord's command and if with their help you are able to conquer the land, then give them the land of Gilead as their property.

Chapter 32.32:30: But if they do not cross the Jordan and go into battle with you, they are to receive their share of the property in the land of Canaan, as you do.

Chapter 32.32:31: The men of Gad and Reuben answered, Sir, we will do as the Lord has commanded.

Chapter 32.32:32: Under his command we will cross into the land of Canaan and go into battle, so that we can retain our property here east of the Jordan.

Chapter 32.32:33: So Moses assigned to the tribes of Gad and Reuben and to half the tribe of Manasseh all the territory of King Sihon of the Amorites and King Og of Bashan, including the towns and the country around them.

Chapter 32.32:34: The tribe of Gad rebuilt the fortified towns of Dibon, Ataroth, Aroer,

Chapter 32.32:37: The tribe of Reuben rebuilt Heshbon, Elealeh, Kiriathaim,

Chapter 32.32:38: Nebo, Baal Meon this name was changed, and Sibmah. They gave new names to the towns they rebuilt.

Chapter 32.32:39: The clan of Machir son of Manasseh invaded the land of Gilead, occupied it, and drove out the Amorites who were there.

Chapter 32.32:40: So Moses gave Gilead to the clan of Machir, and they lived there.

Chapter 32.32:41: Jair, of the tribe of Manasseh, attacked and captured some villages and named them Villages of Jair.

Chapter 32.32:42: Nobah attacked and captured Kenath and its villages, and he renamed it Nobah, after himself.

Chapter 35.35:18: If, however, any of you use a weapon of iron or stone or wood to kill someone, you are guilty of murder and are to be put to death.

Chapter 35.35:19: The dead person's nearest relative has the responsibility for putting the murderer to death. When he finds you, he is to kill you.

Chapter 35.35:20: If you hate someone and kill him by pushing him down or by throwing something at him

Chapter 35.35:21: or by striking him with your fist, you are guilty of murder and are to be put to death. The dead person's nearest relative has the responsibility for putting the murderer to death. When he finds you, he is to kill you.

Chapter 35.35:22: But suppose you accidentally kill someone you do not hate, whether by pushing him down or by throwing something at him.

Chapter 35.35:23: Or suppose that, without looking, you throw a stone that kills someone whom you did not intend to hurt and who was not your enemy.

Chapter 35.35:24: In such cases the community shall judge in your favor and not in favor of the dead person's relative who is seeking revenge.

Chapter 35.35:25: You are guilty only of manslaughter, and the community is to rescue you from the dead person's relative, and they are to return you to the city of refuge to which you had escaped. You must live there until the death of the man who is then High Priest.

Chapter 35.35:26: If you leave the city of refuge to which you have escaped

Chapter 35.35:27: and if the dead person's relative finds you and kills you, this act of revenge is not murder.

Chapter 35.35:28: Any of you guilty of manslaughter must remain in the city of refuge until the death of the High Priest, but after that you may return home.

Chapter 35.35:29: These rules apply to you and your descendants wherever you may live.

Chapter 35.35:30: Those accused of murder may be found guilty and put to death only on the evidence of two or more witnesses; the evidence of one witness is not sufficient to support an accusation of murder.

Chapter 35.35:31: Murderers must be put to death. They cannot escape this penalty by the payment of money.

Chapter 35.35:32: If they have fled to a city of refuge, do not allow them to make a payment in order to return home before the death of the High Priest.

Chapter 35.35:33: If you did this, you would defile the land where you are living. Murder defiles the land, and except by the death of the murderer there is no way to perform the ritual of purification for the land where someone has been murdered.

Chapter 35.35:34: Do not defile the land where you are living, because I am the Lord and I live among the people of Israel.

Chapter 36.36:1: The heads of the families in the clan of Gilead, the son of Machir and grandson of Manasseh son of Joseph, went to Moses and the other leaders.

Chapter 36.36:2: They said, The Lord commanded you to distribute the land to the people of Israel by drawing lots. He also commanded you to give the property of our relative Zelophehad to his daughters.

Chapter 36.36:3: But remember, if they marry men of another tribe, their property will then belong to that tribe, and the total allotted to us will be reduced.

Chapter 36.36:4: In the Year of Restoration, when all property that has been sold is restored to its original owners, the property of Zelophehad's daughters will be permanently added to the tribe into which they marry and will be lost to our tribe.

Chapter 36.36:5: So Moses gave the people of Israel the following command from the Lord. He said, What the tribe of Manasseh says is right,

Chapter 36.36:6: and so the Lord says that the daughters of Zelophehad are free to marry anyone they wish but only within their own tribe.

Chapter 36.36:7: The property of every Israelite will remain attached to his tribe.

Chapter 36.36:8: Every woman who inherits property in an Israelite tribe must marry a man belonging to that tribe. In this way all Israelites will inherit the property of their ancestors,

Chapter 36.36:9: and the property will not pass from one tribe to another. Each tribe will continue to possess its own property.

Chapter 36.36:10: So Mahlah, Tirzah, Hoglah, Milcah, and Noah, the daughters of Zelophehad, did as the Lord had commanded Moses, and they married their cousins.

Chapter 36.36:11: So Mahlah, Tirzah, Hoglah, Milcah, and Noah, the daughters of Zelophehad, did as the Lord had commanded Moses, and they married their cousins.

Chapter 36.36:12: They married within the clans of the tribe of Manasseh son of Joseph, and their property remained in their father's tribe.

Chapter 36.36:13: These are the rules and regulations that the Lord gave the Israelites through Moses in the plains of Moab across the Jordan River from Jericho.
